bibl.title: Letter from L. Evans Parcell to Philip Showalter Hench, November 9, 1940

div1.p: Parcell describes the dioramas he has constructed and quotes Hench a price for them.

div1.head: Letter from L. Evans Parcell to Philip Showalter Hench, November 9, 1940
div1.opener:
Dioramas
5213 Fifth Avenue
Pittsburgh, Penna.
November 9, 1940
Dr. P.S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minn.
Dear Sir,
div1.p:
Unforeseen circumstances prevented my
sending these photographs to you earlier. I hope this de-
lay has in no way inconcenienced you.

These photographs will give you some idea
as to the type of dioramas I have built.

No.s I and II were built for the Amer-
ican Radiator and Standard Mfg. Co. of this city.for their
display at the San Francisco and New York World Fairs.

No. I is eight feet long, six feet high,
and three feet deep. No. II is seven feet long, seven feet
high, and three feet deep.

No. I has been purchased by the Museum of
Science and Invention at Rockefellow Center, New York.and
will be on display there permanently.

No. III is a typical old farm built to the
scale of one inch to the foot; the whole occupying about
seven by nine feet.

No. IV is a much smaller diorama, foreground
and figures are in the round, with middle distance and back-
ground being painted upon consecutive layers of glass. This
treatment gives unusual depth and atmosphere but is difficult
to ship.

No.s I and II are built of insulating m
material, wood, and paper mache. They are very light weight,
and permanent and are far superior to plaster paris models,
I suggest this type for the four dioramas you are contemp-
lating because of the distance they are to be shipped.

Since our telephone conversation, I have
given some thought regarding the price for these four
dioramas. Assuming the approximate size of each of the four
around three feet high, four feet long, and thirty inches
deep, I can quote you a price of three thousand dollars, or
thereabout, depending of course, upon more complete data
which I shall need. However, this figure will give you
basis upon which you may compute.

I am hoping you will be able to come to
Pittsburgh in the near future. I will be glad to meet you
and discuss further with you upon this matter.
